## Three new ideas {.smaller }

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
1. Nonstationary models show promise [@schlef_idf:2023;@cheng_nonstationary:2014]...
$$
\begin{aligned}
y_{s,t} &\sim \text{GEV} (\mu_{s,t}, \sigma_{s,t}, \xi_{s,t}) \\
\mu_{s,t} &= \overbrace{\beta_{s}}^\text{spatial coefficient} \times \underbrace{X_t}_\text{climate index} \\
&\text{similar for } \sigma_{s,t}, \xi_{s,t}
\end{aligned}
$$
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
...but exacerbate parametric uncertainties [@montanari_immortal:2014;@serinaldi_undead:2015]
:::

::::
:::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
2. Radar and satellite products offer better coverage at ungauged locations and short durations [@anshsrivastava_raedaridf:2023]...
:::
::: {.fragment .fade-in}
...but is difficult to blend with gauge data
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
----------


3. Estimating multiple durations simultaneously can improve estimates [@ulrich_idf:2020;@koutsoyiannis_idf:1998]...
:::
::: {.fragment .fade-in}
... but are yet to be applied to nonstationary models
:::

::::
:::::

# Our approach

## Overview {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Key assumptions:

:::  {.incremental}
1. The robust effects of climate covariates on the probability distribution of heavy rainfall are heterogeneous in space and
1. Distribution parameters vary smoothly across durations
1. All temporal variation described by climate covariates
:::
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
Key features:

:::  {.incremental}
1. GEV parameters vary as parametric function of duration [@ulrich_idf:2020,@koutsoyiannis:2003]
1. "Climate-informed" nonstationarity [@schlef_idf:2023]
1. Gaussian process to learn and enforce optimal smoothing (*i.e., regionalization*)
:::
:::
::::

# Collaboration?

## Gridded and point data

Gridded and point data measure different things, so we need to be careful about how we combine them.

. . .

:::: {.callout-tip}
## Why not use only gridded data?

::: {.incremental}
1. no sub-hour data
1. short records ➡️ sampling uncertainty
1. dependence on calibration performance at extremes
:::
::::

## How to incorporate satellite data? {.smaller}

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="33%"}
::: {.fragment .fade-in}
#### Spatial dependence

1. We use a Gaussian process (GP) for spatial dependence.
1. The *spatial footprint* of ENSO or CO2 on parameters should be the same in the gridded and point data ➡️ GP parameters should be the same.
:::
::::
:::: {.column width="33%"}
::: {.fragment .fade-in}
#### Duration dependence

1. We parameterize the GEV parameters as a function of duration [@ulrich_idf:2020;@koutsoyiannis_idf:1998]
1. These should be related (though not identical) in the gridded and point data
:::
::::
:::: {.column width="33%"}
::: {.fragment .fade-in}
#### Trends

1. Trends (coefficients) should be similar in the gridded and point data.
1. Trends in gridded data can offer an nformative prior in our Bayesian framework.
:::
::::
:::::
